apps.name: Mahabharat
apps.desc:
This ongoing project serves data from the Mahabharat.
The intention is to build an API. Meanwhile, a query service is available.

apps.name: Mercury
apps.desc: Mercury is a customisable web app that uses the Oxford Dictionaries API to translate words to English. You enter a word in your language, and are shown a list of their English counterparts and how to pronounce them, together with examples to show how to use the words in English sentences.

apps.name: Intro by an ancient child
apps.desc:
A fictional take on life in ancient India.
This web app uses the [Rig Veda API](https://aninditabasu.github.io/indica/api_rv/) and [Vedic Society API](https://aninditabasu.github.io/indica/api_vs/) to generate an 'About Me' of a child of those times. A new 'About Me' is generated with every page refresh.

apps.name: StopWords
apps.desc:
A script that locates non-inclusive language in the docs of a GitHub repo you specify.
The aim is to find (and review and, if needed, remove or rephrase) words and phrases that might not promote accessibility, diversity, or inclusiveness. The app can also be used as a consistency checker for spellings (for example, `plug-in` vs. `plugin` or `color` vs. `colour`) and phrasing (for example, `we recommend` vs. `it is recommended`).

apps.name: Tarz-e-zindagi
apps.desc:
Funky career advice from the Vedas.
Tarz-e-zindagi (lit. manner of living) uses the [Vedic Society API](https://aninditabasu.github.io/indica/api_vs/) to suggest a course to study, a place to study at, the teacher to study under, and the spells and chants needed during the studentship.

apps.name: Alfaaz
apps.desc:
This bot tweets the English meanings of an Urdu word and transliterates the word to the Hindi script.
Word meanings are, in the first instance, from Oxford Dictionaries. If no meaning is found, the fallback dictionaries are the Urdu dictionaries hosted at the Digital South Asia Library by the University of Chicago.
The bot has since ceased to exist.
